name: 4-(Dimethylamino)benzoic acid
Reason: To predict the melting point of 4-(Dimethylamino)benzoic acid, we must consider the impacts of the constituent functional groups relative to a reference compound. Benzene, as the base structure, has a melting point of 5.5 °C. The dimethylamino (-N(CH3)2) group attached to the ring can introduce steric hindrance and increase the molecular weight, which typically raises the melting point; let's estimate this effect to be +50 °C. However, the presence of the nitrogen may also introduce some dipole-dipole interactions, which could elevate the melting point further; so let's adjust this to +70 °C. The carboxylic acid (-COOH) group forms strong intermolecular hydrogen bonds, greatly increasing the melting point. We can estimate this effect to be +180 °C. Adding these together gives us a rough prediction for the melting point of the compound.

name: 4-(Dimethylamino)benzoic acid
Reason:
To predict the melting point of 4-(Dimethylamino)benzoic acid, we look at the contributions of the functional groups present in the compound. Starting with benzene which has a melting point of 5.5 °C as the base structure. The dimethylamino group (
-N(CH3)2) introduces steric hindrance and increases the molecular weight, which generally has an elevating effect on the melting point; we can estimate this increase to be around +40 °C. On top of that, the dimethylamino group introduces extra dipole-dipole interactions due to the presence of the nitrogen atom, contributing an additional +30 °C to the melting point. The carboxylic acid group (-COOH) has a very strong effect on the melting point due to its ability to form robust intermolecular hydrogen bonds with other molecules, this can be estimated to add another +160 °C to the melting point. Summing these effects, we can predict the melting point of the compound.
Prediction: 5.5 (benzene) + 40 (dimethylamino steric hindrance) + 30 (dimethylamino dipole interactions) + 160 (carboxylic acid hydrogen bonding) = 235.5 °C
